intro: Pseudopiptocarpha tovarensis, commonly known as the Tovar Valley thistle, is a flowering plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of the southwestern United States. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads composed of ray and disk florets. The plant typically grows in rocky soils and is adapted to withstand drought conditions. Its leaves are usually gray-green with a fuzzy texture, and it produces small, spiky flower heads that attract pollinators. Pseudopiptocarpha tovarensis plays a role in stabilizing soil and providing habitat for local wildlife.
